cards.back: A fundamental property of matter that causes it to experience a force in an electric field.
Coulombs (C).
Positive and negative.
Coulomb's Law.

The magnitude of the force between two point charges is directly proportional to the product of the charges and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them: **F = k * |q1 * q2| / r²**.

cards.front: Direction of force for like charges?
cards.back: Repulsive.

cards.front: Direction of force for opposite charges?
cards.back: Attractive.
An idealized charge located at a single point in space with negligible size.
The net force on a charge is the vector sum of the forces from all other charges.

cards.front: Unit vector significance in electric force?
cards.back: Indicates the direction of the force in vector form.
E = F / q, where F is the force on a test charge q.
Newtons per Coulomb (N/C) or Volts per meter (V/m).

cards.front: Electric field due to a point charge?
cards.back: E = k * |Q| / r².

cards.front: Direction of electric field from a positive charge?
cards.back: Radially outward.

cards.front: Direction of electric field from a negative charge?
cards.back: Radially inward.
The electric potential energy per unit charge at a point in space.
Volts (V), where 1 V = 1 J/C.

cards.front: Relationship between electric field and potential?
cards.back: E = -dV/dr (the negative gradient of potential).

cards.front: Electric potential of a point charge?
cards.back: V = k * Q / r.
A surface where the electric potential is constant everywhere.

cards.front: Work done moving a charge on an equipotential?
cards.back: Zero, because there is no change in potential.
The net potential at a point is the algebraic sum of potentials due to individual charges.

cards.front: Difference between electric field and electric potential?
cards.back: Electric field is a vector (force per unit charge); potential is a scalar (energy per unit charge).
A small positive charge used to measure electric fields without disturbing them.
Imaginary lines indicating the direction a positive test charge would move.

cards.front: Rules for drawing electric field lines?
cards.back: Start on positive charges, end on negative charges; density indicates field strength; lines never cross.
Two equal and opposite charges separated by a small distance.
p = q * d, where q is charge and d is separation vector; points from negative to positive charge.

cards.front: Electric field on axis of dipole?
cards.back: E ≈ (1 / 4πε₀) * (2p / r³) for far-field along the axis.

cards.front: Electric field on perpendicular bisector of dipole?
cards.back: E ≈ (1 / 4πε₀) * (p / r³) for far-field along the perpendicular bisector.

cards.front: Potential energy of a charge in an electric field?
cards.back: U = q * V.

cards.front: Force on a charge in a uniform electric field?
cards.back: F = q * E.

cards.front: Motion of a charge in uniform E-field?
cards.back: Accelerates in the direction of the force (like a mass in gravity).

cards.front: Relationship between electric potential energy and kinetic energy?
cards.back: Change in potential energy converts to kinetic energy: ΔU = -ΔK.
Material in which charges can move freely.
Material in which charges cannot move freely.
Separation of charges in a neutral object due to an external electric field.
Connecting an object to the Earth so excess charge can flow to or from it.
Φ = E·A·cosθ, measures the number of field lines passing through an area.
The net electric flux through a closed surface equals the charge enclosed divided by ε₀: Φ = Q_enclosed / ε₀.
N·m²/C.
